title.narrative: We Effect Green Enterprise Business Dev
We Effect Green Enterprise Business Dev

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Productive and decent work for rural women and youth through on and off farm green enterprise development. Outcome 2: Farm entrepreneurs applying environmentally sustainable climate smart techniques and practices. Outcome 3: We Effect POs effectively representing rural entrepreneurs, providing demand-driven services and applying a Rights Based Approach.

Kooperation Utan Gränser (We Effect) har inkommit med en ny ansökan om stöd som uppföljning till deras program Green Enterprise and Business Development Programme (EBDP) som genomfördes 2014-2017. Det nya programförslaget bygger på lärdomar och rekommendationer från utvärderingen av det genomförda programmet som bifogas. Det föreslagna programmet syftar främst till att inkludera gröna smarta lösningar för att stärka kvinnor och unga på landsbygden och deras ekomiska ställning för att de ska kunna lyfta sig ur fattigdom. Den primära målgruppen är 67 500 förmånstagare av den fattigaste befolkningen, där ca 80% är kvinnor och ca 20% är unga (16-35 år).
Föreslagen budget för det treåriga programmet är totalt SEK 30 500 000. Kostnad per motagare ligger runt 55 USD per person under de tre åren. I utbytte mot att personerna deltar får de en fördubblad inkomst från ca 1,56 USD per dag till 3,12 USD per person och dag. Projekteringen är att de 67 500 deltagarna tillsammans ska generera ca 460 miljoner USD i inkomster under de tre åren, genom ambassadens investering på ca 3,6 miljoner USD.
Ambassaden bedömer att detta program faller väl inom Sveriges nya strategi för utvecklingssamarbetet med Zimbabwe (2017-2021) främst genom att stärka mål:
1.3 Stärkta förutsättningar för jämställdhet och respekt för mänskliga rättigheter, med fokus på kvinnor och flickor; 3.1 Förbättrade möjligheter till en hållbar försörjning, med fokus på hållbar livsmedelsförsörjning, produktiv sysselsättning med anställningsvillkor, särskilt för kvinnor och ungdomar. 3.3 Förbättrad kapacitet hos aktörer att bidra till miljö- och klimatmässig hållbarhet.
Programmet är del av We Effects globala och regionala strategi. Det faller även väl inom delar av FNs Globala Mål (SDGs); Mål 1 Ingen fattigdom, Mål 2 Ingen hunger, Mål 5 Jämställdhet, Mål 8 Anständiga arbetsvillkor och ekonomisk tillväxt, samt Mål 13 Bekämpa klimatförändringen.
Programmet ska genomföras av We Effect tillsammans med tre partnerorganisationer, som alla arbetar med ett rättighetsperspektiv och aktivt deltagande. Dessa partnerorganisationer har arbetat väl och gick igenom det sk We Effect Screening Tool 2013, innan de blev partnerorganisationer. We Effect har en lång erfarenhet av att arbeta med dessa typer av landsbygdsprogram. We Effect kommer via detta program stödja människor med rådgivning och utbildning, möjlighet att spara eller låna pengar och hjälpa till med affärsutveckling, där syftet är att förbättra arbetsvillkor och ekonomisk tillväxt. Stödet går även till påverkansarbete för regler och reformer som gynnar fattiga. Programmet förespråkar även ett hållbart och klimatanpassat jordbruk. Vidare syftar programmet till att lära målgruppen hur de kan anpassa sig för att hantera ett mer oförutsägbart klimat, det vill säga följderna av klimatförändringarna.
Ambassaden bedömer att programmets val av vilka delar av landet som genomförandet kommer att ske i är väl valda och inte överlappar med andra program som Sverige stödjer i Zimbabwe. Synergier mellan andra program så som Resiliensfonden kommer att uppmuntras. Det förslagna programmet kommer att genomföras i nio distrikt i sammarbete med de tre partnerorganisationerna, vilka arbetar i tre distrikt var. Jekesa Pfungwa Vulingqondo (JPV) kommer att implementera programmet i Umzingwane, Zaka och Chimanimani; Zimbabwe Women's Bureau (ZWB) arbetar i Goromonzi, Mutare Rural och Gweru; samt Self-Help Development Foundation (SHDF) som kommer genomföra sina aktiviteter i Gwanda, Seke och Buhera districts. Samtliga förutom Gwanda är distrikt som We Effect arbetat inom tidigare.
Ambassaden bedömer att detta program kommer att ekonomiskt stärka fattiga och utsatta kvinnor och ungdomar på landsbyggden samt bidra till ekonomisk tillväxt och anständiga arbetsvillkor.

The major problem identified that the Green EBDP plans to address is indicated as the need to deal with economically and environmentally unstainable livelihoods and food insecurity among rural women and young people. In the proposed intervention, to address the identified problems, We Effect plans to work with the three selected partners that plan to provide services that enable rural women, men and youth to identify business opportunities, get access to affordable finance, and manage financially sustainable rural enterprises in the green economy. On the limited knowledge of rights by the target groups, the partners propose to apply the Human Rights Based principles of participation, legitimacy; accountability; non-discrimination; empowerment; and transparency in their planning and implementation of activities. It is anticipated that this will result in the emergence of empowered women and youths with equal rights and opportunities actively participating in enterprise development for decent green job creation that is sustainable and improves their livelihoods. The ultimate aim of the intervention is poverty reduction and creation of a more just society.Currently, there is a limited number of rural men, women and youth managing viable ‘green’ enterprises. Approximately 70 percent of people in Zimbabwe live in rural areas and depend on agriculture for their livelihoods. Few rural people have opportunities for work that is productive and delivers a fair income, job security and social protection for their families. Most smallholder farmers are unable to generate a decent income from their business enterprises. This is mainly due to an unconducive policy environment, limited access to affordable finance, limited knowledge about and access to appropriate technology, markets, limited entrepreneurial mindset, limited value addition of agricultural produce, limited business opportunities in the various agricultural and non-agricultural value chains among others. Besides the above identified limitatations for rural on and off-farm enterprises, women face additional problems identified by We Effect that it aims to address through the proposed intervention. Women are further marginalized by patriarchal systems even though they are the source of most farm labour in the rural areas. They carry out heavy household work but frequently lack control of the productive resources and the income generated from the farming enterprises. Most rural women and young people have limited opportunities to acquire land hence making it very difficult for them to be involved in farming in their own rights. Also, most young people have a negative perception towards smallholder farming mainly because it is associated with living in poverty. Limited opportunities to raise decent income from rural on and off-farm business activities and/or formal employment has resulted in a huge migration of young people to the urban areas. This has in turn contributed to slum-like settlements with related social problems in the urban areas. Another problem is that most on-farm and off farm businesses are not environmentally assessed and may be a cause of health hazard to the entrepreneurs and may result in environmental degradation.Another identified problem among the target groups and districts is the limited application of sustainable agriculture techniques and practices. Many smallholder farmers use unsustainable agricultural practices which contribute to degradation of natural resources including depleted soil fertility, soil erosion, deforestation and pollution of water sources. This is mainly caused by limited knowledge about how to apply sustainable climate-smart agricultural practices such as conservation farming, water harvesting and agroforestry. Most farmers are also not aware of the reduced vulnerability to climate change, safeguarding of healthy food security and the long-term financial gains by the uptake of resilient green technologies.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The achieved results under the spcific project objectives were reported as follows: Outcome 1: Productive and decent work for rural women and youth through on and off farm green enterprise development. During the period January 2020 to December 2020, the Green Enterprise and Business Development Programme (EBDP) managed to reach out to 24 403 entrepreneurs (12 004 Adult Females, 5 385 Adult Males, 5 187 Female Youths and 1 827 Male Youths). This brought the cumulative total reach of the project, since inception, to 116 895 entrepreneurs (74 466 AF, 24 911 AM, 12 769 FY and 4 749 MY) against the original set target of 67 500 beneficiaries. This represented an over-achievement of 173 %. The net income per household from improved business enterprises was reported as USD2 931 which was 48% of the targeted USD6 850. This was due to, among other challenges, entrepreneurs limited access to markets caused by COVID-19 lock down and travel restrictions, successive drought including 2019/2020 and the frequent monetary policy changes. Outcome 2: Farm entrepreneurs applying environmentally sustainable climate smart techniques and practices. In 2020, 26 119 entrepreneurs (20 895 AF and 5 224 AM) applied conservation farming increasing the cumulative figure to 45 129 which was 78% of the third year target. Agroforestry entrepreneurs were 3 079 entrepreneurs (2 463 AF and 616 AM) bringing the cumulative figure since inception of the project to 6 967 (5 574 AF and 1 393 AM) which was 226% of the set target. Under forestry initiative, 4 682 entrepreneurs (3 746 AF and 936 AM) participated in 2020 increasing the cumulative figure to 6 967 which was 24% of the set target. Farmers who grew small grains in 2020 were 9 004 (7 203 AF and 1 801 AM) and the cumulative figure as at year 3 was 14 144 which was 56% of the target for year 3. The main reason to the increase in all categories under this outcome was the increased participation in study circle groups on sustainable agricultural practices, learning from demonstration by lead farmers and training and advice provided by the Environmental and Resilience Officers (EROs) employed by the Partner Organisations (POs) in the nine project districts. Outcome 3: We Effect Partner Organisations (POs) effectively representing rural entrepreneurs, providing demand-driven services and applying a Rights Based Approach. Right holders/Member satisfaction from service delivery by the POs increased during 2018-2020 period compared to the satisfaction rate before that. All partners had improved member satisfaction even though the targeted 5.5 score was not reached. The result was attributed to the GREEN EBDP support that enabled the POs to significantly improve their capacity to provide demand-driven services to their members in the nine districts. The support included funding for activities, training on governance, financial management , business development, financial literacy, principled negotiation, and use of gender champions. Financial Expenditure Report The GREEN EBDP budget during the reporting period was SEK 10 159 508 and expenditure over the period was SEK 8 794 341 translating to utilization of 87 %. Overall utilization since the inception of the programme was at 81 %. The anticipated utilization was reduced due to suspension or postponement of some activities due to Covid 19. Audit Report The general opinion of the audit indicates that things are in place at We Effect and its partners. There was visible application of the recommendations of the previous audit findings. However, We Effect needs to continue to comply with its policies and procedures which are already in place. The audit picked some non-compliance, in some instances, with the procurement policy and the travel policy.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
